content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Anthony Santana: Well, I was born and raised in Providence, Rhode Island, but I actually grew up in a small town in New England—specifically, in a place called Narragansett. My parents were both working-class folks, and while things weren't ever really hard, we never had a lot of extra money either. My dad worked at a local factory for most of his life, and my mom went to community college and worked part-time at a library. I always admired her for that—she was the one who pushed me to value education, even though she didn't have the chance to go to college herself. I was the first in my family to graduate from college, which was a big deal. I studied political science at Brown University, which was pretty intimidating at first, but I found my footing there. I wasn't really into politics growing up, but I became more interested in social issues as I got older, especially after seeing how people in my community were affected by things like healthcare access and education funding. I've always been more of a liberal thinker, and I guess that's why I ended up leaning toward the Democratic Party, even if I don't identify as a super strong Democrat. I've never been married, and I don't really see myself getting married anytime soon—I've been focused on my career and my personal growth. I work full-time now as a policy analyst for a non-profit that focuses on economic equity, which is something I'm really passionate about. I also speak Spanish pretty fluently, which I picked up from my grandmother who grew up in Spain. I've always felt like I had two homes—one in Rhode Island and one in my memories of Spain. I'm pretty content with my life right now, even though it's not perfect. I've had my share of struggles, but I've also had a lot of opportunities, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Anthony Santana: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads moment for me—right after I graduated from college. I had two real options: one was to take a job with a government agency in Washington, D.C., doing policy work, which would have been a stable, well-paying job with good benefits. The other was to stay in Rhode Island and work for a local non-profit that focused on community development and education access. I was torn because the D.C. job would have given me more visibility and potentially more influence on a national level, but I also knew that I wanted to make a real, tangible difference in the place I grew up. I remember talking to my mom about it one night, and she just said, 'You don't have to leave to make an impact. You can be the change right here.' That stuck with me. I ended up taking the non-profit job, and it was one of the best decisions I ever made. I got to work directly with people in my community, see the real effects of policy on a local level, and it solidified my passion for economic equity. I think that choice made me who I am today—someone who values grassroots change over just climbing the ladder.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Anthony Santana: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I didn't sit down and make a grand decision with a list of pros and cons—I just felt it in my gut. I've always been someone who listens more than I speak, and I think that's why I was able to hear my mom's words that night. It wasn't just about the job; it was about where I wanted to be in life. I wanted to be rooted in the community that shaped me, to be someone who could look people in the eye and say, 'I understand where you're coming from.' That feeling was real, and I made a choice based on that. I think sometimes people say it 'just happened' because they don't want to admit they had the power to choose. But I believe we always have a choice—it's just a matter of whether we're brave enough to make it.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Anthony Santana: Absolutely, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've grown older. When I was making that decision about the job, my mom was definitely a big influence, but I also had a mentor at the non-profit who really believed in my potential. Her name was Maria, and she had been working in community development for over 20 years. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time, and she encouraged me to take the leap. She even offered to help me with the transition, introducing me to people in the field and giving me advice on how to navigate the work. Without her support, I don't know if I would have had the confidence to stay in Rhode Island. It's funny, though—I think sometimes we underestimate the role that other people play in our decisions. We like to think we're making choices all on our own, but the truth is, we're always standing on the shoulders of others.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Anthony Santana: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children, and I don't see that changing in the near future. I've been focused on my work and personal growth, and honestly, I don't know if I'm ready for the responsibilities that come with a relationship or family life. That said, I have a close-knit family that I value a lot. My parents are still in Narragansett, and even though I live in Providence now, I make it a point to visit them as often as I can. My mom, in particular, has been a huge support system for me—she's the one who always reminds me to take time for myself and not get too caught up in work. My dad, while not as involved in my day-to-day life, has always been there with a joke or a story about his time at the factory. I also have an older sister who lives in Boston; she's a nurse, and we talk almost every week. She's the one who keeps me grounded, even when I'm getting too deep into policy debates. I don't think I'd ever want to be completely alone, but I also don't feel the need to rush into anything. For now, my family is my anchor, and I'm grateful for them.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and choices I've made. From my upbringing in Narragansett to the decision I made after college, each step has led me to where I am today—working in economic equity and staying rooted in the community that raised me. It's interesting how the questions brought up the importance of my mom's influence, my mentor Maria, and the values I hold about making a difference in the real world. I never really thought about how much my life has been a series of conscious choices, even if they didn't feel like grand decisions at the time. I'm grateful for the support system I have, especially my family, and I think that's why I feel content with my life right now. I may not have a partner or children, but I have a strong foundation of love and purpose, and that's something I don't take for granted.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Anthony Santana: My immediate family is pretty small—just my parents, my sister, and me. We don't have any extended family living nearby, but we're all very close. My grandparents on my mom's side passed away a few years ago, but I still remember them fondly. My grandfather was a big influence on me; he had a love for storytelling and history, and he always made me feel like I could achieve anything if I worked hard enough. My grandmother, as I mentioned before, was from Spain, and she taught me Spanish when I was a kid. She used to tell me stories about growing up in Seville, and I think that's where my love for language and culture came from. Even though she's not around anymore, I still feel her presence in my life, especially when I'm speaking Spanish or cooking traditional dishes. I don't have any siblings other than my older sister, and while we're very different in terms of personalities and careers, we share a deep respect for each other. She's the one who always reminds me to stay humble, and I think that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Anthony Santana: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been really important to me. One of them is Jamal, who I met during my time at Brown. He was a sociology major, and we bonded over our shared interest in social justice issues. He's the one who introduced me to a lot of the local activists in Providence, and through him, I got involved in some community organizing efforts that really shaped my career path. We haven't stayed in touch as much as I'd like, but I still respect him a lot and think about him often. Then there's my coworker, Elena, who I've been working with for the past few years. She's been a great mentor and friend—she's always pushing me to think more critically about the policies we work on and to stay connected to the people we're trying to help. I also have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, even though we all went different ways after graduation. They're the ones who remind me to have fun and not take life too seriously. I think it's important to have people in your life who challenge you, support you, and just make you laugh. I'm lucky to have that.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Anthony Santana: I live in a neighborhood in Providence called Fox Point. It's a pretty tight-knit area, with a lot of historic homes and a strong sense of community. There are a few small businesses, some great coffee shops, and a community center that hosts events throughout the year. I really like that it's not too far from downtown, but still has that local feel. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a converted townhouse, and it's actually pretty cozy. The building has a small courtyard where people gather on nice days, and I've gotten to know a few of my neighbors over the years. One of them is an artist named Luis, who lives across the hall—he's always painting or working on some kind of sculpture. We don't talk much, but I appreciate the creativity around me. The area has its challenges, like with gentrification and rising rents, which is something I've been thinking a lot about in my work. I want to make sure that places like Fox Point remain accessible to the people who have lived here for generations. It's a part of the city that has a rich history, and I feel lucky to be a part of it, even if just for now.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Anthony Santana: I feel pretty safe in Fox Point, honestly. It's not perfect—like anywhere else—it has its issues, but I've never felt threatened or unsafe in my own neighborhood. There's a sense of familiarity here, and I think that makes a big difference. I know most of the people who live around me, at least by face, and there's a mutual respect that comes with that. That said, I do worry about how gentrification is changing things. I've seen some long-time residents move out because of rising rents, and it's sad. I don't want to see the character of the neighborhood disappear just because it's becoming more expensive. Safety is about more than just crime—it's about who gets to feel welcome and protected in a place. I hope that as the neighborhood changes, it still stays a place where people like me, who grew up here, can afford to stay.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Anthony Santana: Living here has had its ups and downs, for sure. On the positive side, I love the sense of community that still exists in Fox Point. Even with the changes, there's a real connection between neighbors, and I've made some good friends through the local events and the community center. I also appreciate being close to downtown—there's always something going on, whether it's a concert in the park or a new restaurant opening. But the downs? Well, the cost of living has definitely been a challenge. I've had to be careful with my budget, especially with rent and utilities, and it's something I think about a lot in my work. I want to make sure that people who have lived here for years aren't priced out, and I know that's a fight I'm going to be part of for a while. It's not just about the money, though—it's about belonging. I want to feel like I'm part of something bigger, and I think that's why I stay here, even when it's tough.

Going through the questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my roots and environment shape who I am. It's easy to get caught up in the work I do and the goals I set, but these conversations reminded me of the importance of the people and places that have supported me along the way. My family, especially my mom and sister, have been constants in my life, and I'm grateful for their love and guidance. Living in Fox Point has given me a sense of belonging, even as I watch it change. I hope I can be part of the solution to make sure that change doesn't come at the cost of the community's soul. It's not just about where I live—it's about who gets to live here, and that's something I care deeply about.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Anthony Santana: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work deadlines and community events. I usually start my week early—around 6:30 a.m.—with a quick workout at the local gym, which is actually a community center that offers free classes to residents. After that, I head to my office, which is just a 15-minute walk from my apartment. My days are mostly spent analyzing data, drafting reports, and meeting with stakeholders to discuss policy proposals. Mondays are usually the busiest, with team meetings and strategy sessions. Tuesdays and Wednesdays tend to be more focused on individual work, like researching new programs or writing grants. Thursdays are often spent in the field—visiting schools, community centers, or talking to residents about their experiences with local policies. Fridays are a bit more relaxed, but I still have meetings or events to attend. I try to end my workday around 5:30 p.m. and then head home for dinner. On weekends, I like to spend time with my family or catch up with friends. I also volunteer at a local food pantry once a month, which is something I really value. It keeps me connected to the community and reminds me why I do the work I do. Even though my schedule can be demanding, I find balance in the rhythm of it all, and I think that's what keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Anthony Santana: I work as a policy analyst for a non-profit organization called Rhode Island Equity Now, which focuses on economic equity and community development. My main role is to analyze data, draft policy proposals, and work with local stakeholders to create programs that help low-income families access better education, housing, and job opportunities. I work full-time, Monday through Friday, from around 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., though I often stay late a few days a week when I'm working on big projects or preparing for meetings. I also do some evening work from home, especially when I'm reviewing reports or collaborating with colleagues in different time zones. The job is demanding, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I get to see the real impact of policy work on people's lives, and that keeps me motivated. I've been in this role for about three years now, and it's become a big part of who I am. I think that's why I'm so passionate about it—I don't just want to analyze policies; I want to help shape them in a way that makes a real difference for people in my community.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Anthony Santana: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I've always been into music, and I play the guitar in my free time. I took lessons when I was younger, and even though I haven't played as much in recent years, I still find it therapeutic. I usually set aside an hour or two on weekends to practice or just sit and strum a song while I think. It's my way of unwinding and connecting with something creative. I also enjoy cooking, especially experimenting with Spanish dishes that my grandmother used to make. There's something comforting about making food that reminds me of her, even if I'm not perfect at it. I've been trying to get better at it, and I've even started teaching a few friends how to make some of her favorite recipes. It's funny, really—life has this way of bringing people together through simple things like food and music. I think those little rituals are what keep me grounded, especially when the work gets heavy.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Anthony Santana: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into my mornings. I used to just jump out of bed and head straight to the gym, but I've started taking 10 to 15 minutes to sit quietly, maybe with some light stretching or just breathing deeply. It's something I picked up from a friend who works in mental health, and I've found it really helps me center myself before the day begins. I also started journaling again, which I hadn't done in a while. It's been a way to process everything I'm working on at the non-profit and just reflect on my thoughts. I think it's important to take a moment for yourself, especially when you're trying to make a difference in the world. It's easy to get caught up in the hustle, but I've realized that if I don't take care of myself first, I can't show up fully for others. So, these small changes have been a way for me to stay grounded and present, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Anthony Santana: I don't have children, but I can tell you about what my life would be like if I did. If I had kids, I'd want them to grow up with the same values I was raised with—like the importance of education, community, and kindness. I imagine a typical weekday during the school year would start with them getting up early, maybe around 7 a.m., after a good night's sleep. I'd make sure they had a healthy breakfast, maybe something like eggs and whole-grain toast with a side of fruit. Then they'd head off to school, and I'd try to be involved in their day as much as possible—whether it was volunteering at the school or just checking in with their teachers. After school, I'd hope they'd have time for some kind of activity they loved, whether it was sports, music, or art. I'd support them in whatever they were passionate about, just like my mom supported me. In the evenings, we'd have dinner together, and I'd make sure there was time for conversation and connection. I think family meals are so important, and I'd want that to be a part of their routine. Even though I don't have kids now, I think about what kind of parent I'd want to be, and I know it would be someone who listens, encourages, and always tries to lead by example.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my roots and daily routines shape who I am. Thinking about my family, my neighborhood, and the rhythm of my life reminded me of how much I value the people and places that have supported me. My mom and sister have always been there for me, and I'm grateful for their love and guidance. Living in Fox Point has given me a sense of belonging, even as I watch it change. I hope I can be part of the solution to make sure that change doesn't come at the cost of the community's soul. It's not just about where I live—it's about who gets to live here, and that's something I care deeply about. My work as a policy analyst is driven by this sense of responsibility to my community, and my daily routines—whether it's playing guitar, cooking, or volunteering—help me stay grounded and connected to the people I serve.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Anthony Santana: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty fortunate. I've always been active, even as a kid—I was the type of kid who would run around the neighborhood instead of sitting still. I still try to keep that up, which is why I make time for a morning workout most days. I've been going to the gym at the community center for a few years now, and I've noticed that it helps me stay focused and energized throughout the day. I also try to eat pretty well—nothing too strict, but I make an effort to cook at home, especially on weekends. I've been working on eating more whole foods and cutting back on processed stuff, which has made a difference in how I feel. That said, I'm not perfect. I do get stressed sometimes, especially with the work I do, and I've had to learn how to manage that better. I started seeing a therapist a few months ago, which has been really helpful. It's not that I was struggling with anything major, but I realized I needed to take a closer look at how I handle pressure and maintain my mental health. I think it's important to be proactive about that, especially when you're in a line of work where you're constantly dealing with challenges. Overall, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape, both physically and mentally, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Anthony Santana: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that I can rely on—like my morning workouts and the meals I prepare at home. I think consistency is key, and when I stick to those habits, it feels less like a chore and more like part of my day. What makes it harder, though, is the stress that comes with my work. There are days when I'm so caught up in deadlines or policy debates that I forget to take breaks or eat properly. I've had to remind myself that taking care of my health isn't just about physical fitness—it's also about mental well-being. I've started setting small reminders on my phone to take deep breaths or stretch during the workday, and that's helped a lot. It's not always easy, but I've come to see health as something I need to nurture, just like any other part of my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Anthony Santana: In the past two years, I've been pretty healthy overall, but there was one incident that stands out. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent lower back pain after a long day at the office. At first, I thought it was just from sitting too much or maybe a minor strain, but it didn't go away. I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist, and it turned out to be a combination of poor posture and muscle tension from carrying a lot of stress. The therapist worked with me on some exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture, and I also started incorporating more stretching into my daily routine. It was a wake-up call for me—reminding me that even if I'm physically active, I can still neglect other parts of my body. Since then, I've been more mindful of how I sit, stand, and move throughout the day. I also started taking short walks during my lunch break, which has helped a lot. It wasn't a major health issue, but it was a reminder that taking care of my body is an ongoing process, not something I can just check off once in a while.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Anthony Santana: Honestly, the back pain didn't really interfere with my work or my ability to care for others, but it did make me realize how much I take my body for granted. I've always been pretty active, so it was surprising to feel like something was holding me back, even if it was just minor discomfort. What it did do, though, was make me more aware of how stress and posture can affect your physical health in ways you don't always notice. I think that's something a lot of people in my line of work deal with—we're constantly thinking, analyzing, and problem-solving, and it can take a toll if you're not careful. I've made some changes to my routine to prevent it from happening again, like taking more breaks during the day and making sure I'm not hunching over my desk for hours at a time. It's not just about staying healthy for the sake of it—it's about being able to show up for the people I care about and the work I do. I don't want to be someone who's always pushing through pain or burnout, because that doesn't help anyone in the long run.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Anthony Santana: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly grounded, but also a little reflective. There's been a lot of growth in my work, especially with some of the policy initiatives we've been pushing for economic equity in Providence. It's been rewarding to see some of the programs we advocated for actually get implemented, like the new community education grants and the housing assistance pilot. But with that comes a lot of pressure, and I've had to be really intentional about how I manage my energy. I think I've been more aware of my mental health than ever before, which is a good thing. I've also been trying to reconnect with parts of my identity that I sometimes neglect, like my Spanish roots. I've been cooking more of my grandmother's recipes and even started learning some traditional songs on the guitar. It's been a way to honor her memory and keep that part of my heritage alive. I've also been thinking a lot about the future—where I want to take my work, how I want to contribute to my community, and what kind of impact I want to leave behind. It's not always easy to balance all of that, but I feel like I'm in a good place, even if I'm still figuring things out.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits shape my ability to show up for the work I do and the people I care about. It's easy to get caught up in the hustle of policy work and forget to take care of myself, but the recent changes I've made—like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings and journaling—have helped me stay grounded. I've also come to realize that health isn't just about physical fitness; it's about mental well-being too. The back pain I experienced was a wake-up call that even small changes in posture and routine can have a big impact. I'm learning to be more proactive about my health, not just for myself, but so I can continue being present for my community and the work I'm passionate about.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Anthony Santana: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I wouldn't say I've been completely free from it. There have been moments—especially during particularly intense periods at work or when I've felt the weight of not making enough progress on the issues I care about—where I've felt a bit overwhelmed or disconnected. I remember one time, a few years back, when I was working on a major policy proposal and I just felt like I was spinning my wheels, no matter how hard I tried. I didn't want to talk about it with anyone because I didn't want to seem like I was failing. But looking back, I realize that was a sign I needed to take a step back and check in with myself. That's why I started seeing a therapist—it wasn't because I was in crisis, but because I wanted to be more proactive about my mental health. I think it's important to recognize that even if you're not in a place of severe struggle, you can still benefit from support and reflection. I've learned that it's okay to not be okay all the time, and that taking care of your mental health is just as important as taking care of your physical health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Anthony Santana: For my family, the past year has been a mix of stability and quiet growth. My mom has been doing well, though she's had to adjust to some changes in her health. She's been going to the doctor more regularly now, which is something I'm really grateful for. She still keeps busy with her gardening and her book club, which is a big part of her life. My dad, on the other hand, has been more reflective lately. He's been telling stories about his time at the factory, and I've been listening a lot more than I used to. It's funny how time changes the way we see things—I used to think he was just telling stories to pass the time, but now I realize they're a way for him to connect with me and share the lessons he learned from his work. My sister has been going through a lot with her nursing job, especially with the ongoing healthcare challenges in Boston. She's been working long hours, but she still makes time to call me and check in. I think she sees me as a kind of anchor, just like I see her. Even though we're all dealing with our own things, I feel like we're all holding on to each other, and that's something I'm really thankful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Anthony Santana: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't played a central role in my life, though I've always had a deep respect for the ways people find meaning and connection through faith. Growing up, my family wasn't religious, and I never really felt the need to fill that space with something formal. That said, I think there's a kind of spirituality in the everyday moments—like the way my mom always makes time for her garden, or how my sister finds purpose in helping others through her nursing work. I don't believe in a higher power in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the power of human connection, the importance of community, and the value of doing what you can to make the world a little better. I think that's where my sense of purpose comes from. It's not about praying or going to church—it's about showing up for the people around me, staying rooted in the values I was raised with, and trying to leave things better than I found them. I don't think I'd ever call myself spiritual, but I do think there's something sacred about the relationships and experiences that shape who we are.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Anthony Santana: I don't use social media all that much, honestly. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or phone calls over scrolling through feeds. That said, I do have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family and a few old friends from college. I'll post the occasional photo of my guitar playing or share a recipe I'm trying out, but I'm not really into the whole 'curated life' thing. I think social media can be a powerful tool for connection, especially for people in my line of work who need to stay informed about policy changes or community issues. I follow a few local activists and non-profits, and I think that helps me stay grounded in what's happening in Providence. But I also know that it can be overwhelming if you're not careful. I've seen how it can affect people's mental health, especially when you're constantly comparing your life to others'. For me, it's more about using it as a tool rather than letting it define how I see myself or my work.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Anthony Santana: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've always leaned on my family, friends, or my community first. That said, I do think social media can be a double-edged sword. I've seen people in my field use it to raise awareness or get funding for projects, and that's definitely a valid use. But for me personally, I prefer to keep my support systems offline. When I'm going through something, I'd rather talk to someone in person or over the phone than post about it online. I think there's a difference between sharing your story and seeking help. I've been lucky enough to have people in my life who are always there for me, so I don't feel the need to turn to social media for that kind of support. That being said, I do think it's important to be mindful of how these platforms can affect your mental health, especially if you're not careful with what you consume or how you present yourself.

Going through the questions about my health and how I've been feeling over the past year made me reflect on how deeply my well-being is tied to both my physical habits and my emotional resilience. The back pain I experienced was a wake-up call that even small changes in posture and routine can have a big impact on how I show up for my work and the people I care about. It also reminded me that mental health is just as important as physical health, and that it's okay to seek support when needed—whether through therapy, mindfulness, or simply taking a moment to breathe. I've come to see health not just as something I need to maintain, but as a foundation that allows me to be present for the community I serve and the relationships that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Anthony Santana: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted a bit—there's been more of a balance between the pressure of my work and the things that ground me. I used to feel like I was constantly on edge, especially when I was pushing for policy changes or dealing with tight deadlines. But now, I've started to build in more moments of reflection and self-care. I've been journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions without getting stuck in them. I've also been practicing mindfulness in small ways, like taking a few deep breaths before meetings or stepping outside for a quick walk when I feel overwhelmed. I think the biggest change has been how I view stress itself. I used to see it as something to eliminate, but now I see it as a signal—that when I feel stressed, it's a sign I need to check in with myself and adjust my approach. I've also leaned more into my relationships, whether it's talking to my mom, sharing a meal with my sister, or even just catching up with a friend over coffee. Those moments help me reset and remind me why I do the work I do. It's not about eliminating stress, but learning how to move through it with more intention and care.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Anthony Santana: In terms of making ends meet, I'd say my monthly budget is pretty tight but manageable. My biggest expenses are rent, which takes up about a third of my income, and groceries, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home. I also have a car payment, which is necessary since public transportation isn't always the most convenient in Providence, especially when I need to travel to different parts of the city for work or community events. Utilities and internet are also a regular expense, and I've had to be careful with those costs, especially with the rising prices over the past year. I don't have a lot of debt, which I think is a blessing, but I do try to save a small amount each month for emergencies or unexpected expenses. I also contribute to a retirement fund, even if it's just a small percentage of my income. It's not about luxury—it's about stability. I want to make sure I can keep doing the work I love without the constant worry of not being able to afford my basic needs. I also try to support local businesses when I can, whether it's buying coffee from the corner shop or shopping at the farmers' market. It's a way to give back to the community that's supported me all these years.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Anthony Santana: My household spending last month was around $3,200, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend. The breakdown is pretty standard—rent is the biggest chunk, around $1,200, and then groceries come in at about $600. I try to cook most of my meals at home, which helps keep that cost down, but I do splurge a bit on fresh produce and local meat from the farmers' market. My car payment is around $350, and utilities and internet are another $300 or so. I also set aside about $200 for savings and retirement contributions, even if it's not a lot. I don't have any major debt, which is something I'm really grateful for, but I do have to be careful with my budget, especially with the rising costs of living in Providence. I also spend a little on books and music—mostly for my guitar and to stay inspired. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to keep me comfortable and focused on what matters most.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Anthony Santana: We rent our home, actually. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a converted townhouse in Fox Point. It's not the biggest place, but it's cozy and has a nice little courtyard where people gather on nice days. Renting makes more sense for me right now because I don't want to tie up all my savings in a house, especially with the way the real estate market is in Providence. Plus, I like the flexibility it gives me—knowing I can move if I need to for work or if something changes in my life. I've been lucky to find a place that's close to everything I need, and I'm grateful for that. It's not perfect, but it's home.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Anthony Santana: Over the past year, my bills have definitely had their ups and downs, especially with the seasons and the way life tends to throw things at you. In the winter, my utility bills went up a bit because of heating, and I had to be more careful with my budget to make sure I wasn't overspending. Then, in the spring, I had to pay for a new set of tires for my car, which was unexpected but necessary. I also noticed that my grocery bills fluctuated depending on what was in season and what I needed for work events or meals I cooked for friends. During the holidays, I spent a little more on gifts for my family and some special meals, but I tried to keep it within a reasonable range. One thing that's been consistent is my rent and my car payment—they're the two biggest fixed costs, and they don't really change much. What's interesting is how my expenses have shifted over time. I used to spend more on dining out, but now that I've gotten into cooking more, I've been able to cut back on that. It's funny how small changes in habits can have a real impact on your budget. I've also started tracking my spending more closely, which has helped me stay on top of things and make sure I'm not overspending on things that aren't essential. It's not always easy, but I think being aware of how my bills fluctuate helps me plan better and stay grounded in my financial reality.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and my approach to social media shape my sense of well-being and connection. My family has always been my anchor, and hearing about their experiences and challenges reminded me of how much I value the relationships we've built over the years. My mom's health changes and my dad's stories have made me more aware of how time affects our perspectives and how important it is to stay present with the people we love. At the same time, thinking about my limited use of social media made me consider how much of my identity and sense of connection comes from real, in-person interactions rather than online presence. I've always preferred face-to-face conversations, and I think that's why I don't feel the need to rely on social media for emotional support. It's a reminder that while technology can be a tool for connection, it's the people in my life—my family, friends, and community—that truly keep me grounded.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Anthony Santana: I do save, though it's not a huge amount. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just $100 or so. It's more of a habit than anything else—something that gives me peace of mind knowing that I have a little cushion for unexpected things, like car repairs or a sudden increase in rent. I also try to save in other ways, like setting aside money for gifts or special occasions in advance so I'm not caught off guard. I think it's important to save not just for emergencies, but also for the little things that make life better—like buying a new guitar string or treating myself to a nice meal once in a while. I don't have a lot, but I've learned that even small, consistent savings can add up over time. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared and having the freedom to make choices without constantly worrying about money.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Anthony Santana: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big things like a home, honestly. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, especially with the way the real estate market is in Providence. It's just not practical for someone who wants to stay flexible and focused on their work. That said, I've been trying to build up a little emergency fund, just in case something unexpected comes up—like a sudden medical expense or a car repair. I know from experience that even small savings can make a big difference when you're not prepared. I also save a little each month for things that bring me joy, like buying a new album or treating myself to a nice meal. It's not about accumulating wealth—it's about having the freedom to make choices without constantly worrying about money. I think that's something I've learned over the years, and it's helped me stay grounded even when life gets a little unpredictable.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Anthony Santana: My occupation is as a policy analyst for a non-profit organization called Rhode Island Equity Now, which focuses on economic equity and community development. In this role, I spend a lot of time analyzing data, drafting policy proposals, and working with local stakeholders to create programs that help low-income families access better education, housing, and job opportunities. One of the most important parts of my work is getting out of the office and into the community—whether it's visiting schools, talking to residents about their experiences with local policies, or collaborating with community leaders to design programs that actually meet people's needs. I think the most rewarding part of the job is seeing the real impact of the work we do. For example, when we advocated for a new community education grant program, it was incredible to see it get implemented and help students in underserved neighborhoods access resources they didn't have before. It's not always easy work—policy can be slow-moving and frustrating at times—but I believe in what we're doing, and that keeps me motivated. I also try to stay connected to the people we serve by volunteering at a local food pantry once a month, which reminds me why I do this work in the first place.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Anthony Santana: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, depending on the project cycle. Mondays are typically the busiest, with team meetings and strategy sessions that can run late into the afternoon. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about focused work—analyzing data, drafting reports, and preparing for stakeholder meetings. Thursdays are often spent in the field, visiting schools, community centers, or meeting with residents to understand their needs and experiences. Fridays can be a bit more relaxed, but I still have meetings or events to attend. I try to leave the office by 5:30 p.m. most days, though I often stay late a few times a week when I'm working on big projects or preparing for meetings. I also do some evening work from home, especially when I'm reviewing reports or collaborating with colleagues in different time zones. It's a demanding schedule, but I find balance in the rhythm of it all, and I think that's what keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Anthony Santana: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, especially since the work I do is pretty demanding and requires a lot of attention to detail. That said, I have taken on some side projects or freelance work in the past, especially when I was in school or just starting out in my career. For example, I used to write articles for a local community magazine about social issues and education access, which was a great way to practice my writing and get more involved in the conversations happening in Providence. I also did some volunteer work with a youth mentorship program, which wasn't paid, but it was incredibly rewarding. I think it's important to stay engaged with your community in different ways, even if it's not through a full-time job. But for the most part, I've been focused on my work at Rhode Island Equity Now, and I don't see myself branching out into other jobs anytime soon. I think having one clear focus helps me stay productive and present for the people I serve.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being and financial stability are deeply connected to the people and habits that ground me. The changes I've made in managing my stress—like journaling, mindfulness, and leaning into my relationships—have helped me stay centered, even when the work gets intense. At the same time, thinking about my monthly budget and how I make ends meet reminded me of the importance of balance—not just in my finances, but in how I approach life overall. I've come to see that stability isn't about perfection; it's about being intentional with my time, money, and emotional energy. I'm grateful for the support of my family, the small savings I've built, and the routines that keep me connected to what matters most. It's all part of the same journey—staying rooted in the community that shaped me, while also taking care of myself so I can keep showing up for the people I care about.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Anthony Santana: In terms of my household income, we made around $4,500 last month. That's pretty much in line with what I usually earn, considering my salary as a policy analyst. I don't have any other sources of income, so it's all based on my full-time job. I try to budget carefully, making sure that my expenses don't exceed what I bring in. I've been lucky to have a stable income, which has allowed me to save a little and also contribute to my retirement fund. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to keep me comfortable and focused on the work I do. I also try to support local businesses when I can, whether it's buying coffee from the corner shop or shopping at the farmers' market. It's a way to give back to the community that's supported me all these years.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Anthony Santana: I've been at Rhode Island Equity Now for about three years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a non-profit—health insurance is covered, though it's not the most comprehensive plan, but it's enough to get me through check-ups and prescriptions. We get a decent amount of paid time off, which is something I really appreciate, especially since I've been working long hours on some projects. I get about two weeks of vacation a year, and I try to use that time to recharge, whether it's going on a road trip with my sister or just taking a few days to be alone with a book and my guitar. We also have sick days, which is important because I've learned that taking time to rest when I'm not feeling well is crucial for staying productive in the long run. One of the things I like most about the job is the flexibility—it's not as rigid as a government position, and that gives me the space to be creative and really connect with the people we're trying to help. I think the benefits aren't just about the money or the insurance; they're about the freedom to show up as my best self, both for the work and for the people I care about.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Anthony Santana: My relationships at work are pretty much what I'd call collaborative and supportive. I have a good rapport with my manager, Elena, who I mentioned earlier. She's not just a boss—she's more like a mentor. She's always pushing me to think critically about the policies we're working on and to stay connected to the people we're trying to help. I trust her judgment, and I know she has my back, even when I'm not sure about a decision. As for my coworkers, we have a pretty tight-knit team. We've been through a lot together—late nights, tight deadlines, and the occasional policy debate that gets heated—but we always come back to the same goal: making a real difference in people's lives. I think that shared purpose is what keeps us connected. We don't just see each other as colleagues; we see each other as people who care about the same things. I've been lucky to work with people who are not only smart and driven but also kind and genuine. That makes a huge difference, especially in a job that can sometimes feel overwhelming.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Anthony Santana: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. Most days, I start around 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:30 p.m., but I often stay late a few times a week, especially when we're working on big projects or preparing for meetings. The flexibility comes in when I need to adjust my hours for fieldwork or when I have to attend community events. For example, if I'm visiting a school or meeting with stakeholders, I might leave the office a bit earlier or stay later depending on how things go. I also have the option to work from home a couple of days a week, which is helpful when I need to focus on a report or when I'm feeling overwhelmed. That said, there are times when the schedule can be less predictable, especially during policy debates or when we're pushing for something that requires a lot of coordination. I think the balance between structure and flexibility is what makes this job work for me—it gives me the stability I need while still allowing me to be responsive to the needs of the community we serve.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Anthony Santana: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, even if it's not what I would call 'stable' in the traditional sense. I don't have a lot of savings, and I'm definitely not rolling in wealth, but I've managed to build a life that allows me to do the work I care about and stay connected to the people who matter most. I know I could be making more money in a different field, maybe something like corporate consulting or government work, but I've always valued purpose over paycheck. That said, I'm not naive—I know that financial security is important, and I've had to make some tough choices to keep things manageable. I've cut back on non-essentials, like dining out or buying things I don't really need, and I've learned to be really intentional with my budget. I also try to support myself through the work I do, whether it's through grants, community partnerships, or even the occasional speaking engagement. I don't see myself getting rich, but I don't need to. What I do have is a sense of freedom—freedom to live in the neighborhood I grew up in, to work on issues that matter to me, and to be present for my family. I think that's something a lot of people would trade a bigger paycheck for, and I'm grateful for that.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule made me reflect on how much my daily life is shaped by the balance between responsibility and intentionality. Thinking about how my bills fluctuate with the seasons and unexpected expenses reminded me of the importance of staying mindful of my finances, even when things feel stable. It's easy to get caught up in the rhythm of work and community involvement, but I've come to appreciate how small habits—like tracking my spending or setting aside money for savings—help me stay grounded. At the same time, reflecting on my work schedule and the flexibility it offers has made me realize how lucky I am to have a job that allows me to be present for both my work and my personal life. I don't have a lot, but I've learned that stability doesn't always mean having everything—it means making choices that align with what truly matters to me, whether that's my family, my community, or the work I do to make a difference.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Anthony Santana: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were pretty different. My dad worked at a local factory for most of his life—he started there right after high school and stayed there until he retired a few years ago. It wasn't the most glamorous job, but it gave him a steady income and a sense of purpose. He always said he liked the rhythm of the work, the way the machines would hum and the way the guys on the line would joke around between shifts. He never had a lot of money, but he always made sure we had what we needed. My mom, on the other hand, worked part-time at the library after she finished community college. She was always the one pushing me to value education, even though she didn't have the chance to go to college herself. She worked nights sometimes so she could study during the day, and she always made time for me, even when things were tough. I think that's why I ended up valuing education so much—it wasn't just about the degrees or the opportunities; it was about the sacrifices they made to give me a better shot at life. Looking back, I realize how much their work shaped who I am today—not just financially, but in terms of the values they passed down.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Anthony Santana: My dad's job at the factory was pretty straightforward—he worked on the assembly line, putting together parts for industrial machinery. It was repetitive work, but he found a kind of rhythm in it. He'd start his shift early in the morning, usually around 6 a.m., and work until 3 p.m. or so. The most important part of his job, he always said, was making sure everything was done right, even if no one was watching. He took pride in that, in knowing that the machines he helped build were going to be used by people all over the country. He never talked about the hardships, like the long hours or the physical toll it took on his body, but I could see it in the way he moved after work—his back would always be a little hunched, and his hands would be calloused from years of handling metal. My mom, on the other hand, worked at the library as a circulation assistant. Her job was more about people than machines. She checked books in and out, helped kids find the right section for their school projects, and always made time to talk to the regulars who came in every day. She loved that part of it—the way she could connect with people through stories and knowledge. Her most important duty, she told me, was making sure the library felt like a place people wanted to be, not just a place to get books. I think that's why I ended up valuing education so much—it wasn't just about the books or the degrees, but about the way my parents showed me that work could be meaningful, even if it wasn't always glamorous.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Anthony Santana: My dad worked for a local manufacturing company called Narragansett Industrial Equipment, which was one of the bigger employers in our town. They made parts for everything from construction machinery to agricultural tools. It was a family-owned business for a long time, and my dad was one of the original workers who started there right after high school. He didn't have a lot of formal training, but he learned the trade through experience, and he was pretty good at it. My mom worked at the Providence Public Library, which was a branch in our town. It was a small library, but it was a hub for the community—people would come in for books, study spaces, or just to hang out. She made sure that everyone felt welcome, and she always had a smile for the kids who came in looking for books for school projects. She didn't make a lot of money, but she never complained about it. She always said that the work she did mattered, even if it wasn't glamorous. Looking back, I think that's what shaped me the most—seeing how both of them worked hard, not for wealth, but for the people they cared about and the values they wanted to pass down.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Anthony Santana: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but maybe with a little more influence and a little more impact. I hope I'm still rooted in Providence, still fighting for economic equity and community development, but maybe I've had the chance to lead a bigger initiative or help shape a policy that really changes lives in a meaningful way. I also hope I'm still playing guitar, still cooking my grandmother's recipes, and still spending time with my family. I don't know if I'll ever have a partner or children, but I hope I'm surrounded by people who care about me and the work I do. I hope I'm still grounded, still connected to the community that raised me, and still learning. I think the most important thing is that I'm still showing up for the people who need me, and that I'm still trying to make the world a little better, even if it's just one person at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Anthony Santana: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection to the people who have shaped me, the community that continues to inspire me, and the work that gives my days meaning. I value the relationships I have with my family, especially my mom and sister, because they've been my constant support system through everything. I value the people I work with, the activists, the community leaders, and the residents who remind me why I do this work. I value the little things too—the sound of my guitar, the smell of my grandmother's cooking, the way the sun feels in Fox Point in the morning. I think what I value most is the ability to show up for others, to be present in a way that makes a difference, even if it's small. I don't need a lot to feel fulfilled, but I do need to feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. That's what keeps me going.

Going through the questions about my work, relationships at the workplace, and the predictability of my schedule made me reflect on how much my job shapes not just my financial stability, but also my sense of purpose and connection. Being at Rhode Island Equity Now for three years has allowed me to grow both professionally and personally, and I'm grateful for the supportive environment I've found there. My manager, Elena, has been more of a mentor than a boss, and that kind of relationship makes a huge difference in how I show up for my work. The flexibility of my schedule gives me the space to be present for both my community and my personal life, which is something I value deeply. I've come to see that work isn't just about the hours or the paycheck—it's about the people you work with, the impact you make, and the freedom to be yourself while doing it. I'm lucky to have a job that allows me to do all of that, and I hope I can keep showing up for the people and the work that matter most to me.

Going through this complete interview and life story has given me a deeper understanding of how much my roots, choices, and the people around me have shaped who I am today. From growing up in Narragansett, being raised by hardworking parents who valued education and community, to making the conscious decision to stay in Rhode Island and work for economic equity, every step has led me to this place in my life. It's amazing how reflecting on these moments has reminded me of the importance of family, the power of community, and the impact of small, intentional choices. I've always known that my work matters, but hearing it all laid out—my struggles, my growth, my gratitude—has made me realize how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have supported me. I may not have a lot, but I have a life filled with purpose, love, and the people who keep me grounded. I'm grateful for this journey, and I hope to continue showing up for the community that shaped me, one step at a time.
